content.content: 楽(たの)しい • (tanoshii) -i (adverbial 楽(たの)しく (tanoshiku))

⟨tano₁siki₁⟩ → */tanʷosikʲi/ → /tanoshii/
From Old Japanese. First attested in the Kojiki of 712 CE. No Ryukyuan cognates exist; as a result, further derivation unknown. Theories include:
* A compound of 手 (ta, “hand”, combining form) + 伸す (nosu, “to extend”)
*: This is problematic, as nosu has first been attested starting from the early 900s, with no A/B distinction (see Jōdai Tokushu Kanazukai for details).
* From 田神 (tano, literally “rice paddy god”)
*: No reading of 神 (*no, “god”) exists.
* A borrowing from an unknown language
*: No words resemble *tanV meaning "fun" or "to enjoy".
好(す)き • (suki) -na (adnominal 好(す)きな (suki na), adverbial 好(す)きに (suki ni))

The 連(れん)用(よう)形(けい) (ren'yōkei, “stem or continuative form”) of the verb 好(す)く (suku, “to like, to be fond of, to enjoy, to feel love for”).
First cited to the late 900s in the 宇津保物語 (Utsubo Monogatari).
好きな食べ物は？ アイスクリームです。
What's your favorite food? - It's ice cream.
君が好きだからこそこれほど頑張っているんだよ。
It's precisely because I like you [because of my fondness for you] that I'm working this hard.
“I like you.” → idiomatically used to express: “I love you.”
どうとも好きにしなさい。
Feel free to do as you like.
狸(たぬき) or 狸(タヌキ) • (tanuki)
According to one theory, derived from 手貫 (tanuki, “arm glove, gauntlet”), which raccoon dog hide was sometimes used for.
狸 兼名苑云狸［音𨤲和名太奴木］摶鳥為粮者也
Raccoon dog: According to Jian Ming Yuan (兼名苑), raccoon dogs [read as 𨤲 (ri), native Japanese 太奴木 (tanuki)] always prey on birds.
アライグマなら尻尾にシマがある。どう見でもタヌキだ。
If you're a raccoon, you'd have stripes on your tail. No matter how you look at it, you're a raccoon dog.

content: a person who pretends to be good but in fact is cunning (compare English sly fox)
short for 狸饂飩 (tanuki-udon) and 狸蕎麦 (tanuki-soba): styles of various noodle dishes
short for 狸寝入り (tanuki neiri): pretending to be asleep

content.content: 狸を決め込む ― tanuki o kimekomu ― pretend to be a raccoon dog → feign sleep

content: short for 狸汁 (tanuki-jiru): a soup made from tanuki meat mixed with daikon, burdock root, etc.

content.content: 走(はし)る • (hashiru) intransitive godan (stem 走(はし)り (hashiri), past 走(はし)った (hashitta))
マラソン選手が走り出した。

content: to move forward; (of a machine) to operate, function; (of objects) to move at a high speed (of a vehicle)

content.content: A car is running. / Cars are running.
The water runs over the stones.

content: to run through some kind of place

content.content: 彼はこの道をよく走る。
He often runs down this street.
The sword slides out of its sheath.

content: to give over oneself to; to commit oneself to (usually something bad)

content.content: 立場を忘れて感情に走ってはいけない。
Don't forget your stance and give in to emotions.

content: to spread out, scatter, splatter, spout
to lead or extend in a certain direction

content.content: I felt a brief pain in my back.

content: to feel palpitations; to have a sense of unease
five colors (usu. red (赤), blue (青), yellow (黄), white (白) and black (黒))

content.content: お腹(なか)が空(す)いた • (onaka ga suita)
The perfective form of お腹が空く (onaka ga suku, “to become hungry”, literally “one's stomach becomes empty”).

⟨ke₁ pu⟩ → */kʲepu/ → /keɸu/ → */kewu/ → /keu/ → /kjoː/
From Old Japanese けふ (ke₁pu), from Proto-Japonic *kepu.
Originally a compound of 此 (ke, apophonic form of ko, "this") + 日 (fu, apophonic form of hi, “day”). The final /eu/ → /joː/ sound shift is a separate but regular phonological change.
梓弓をして春雨けふ降りぬあすさへ降らば若菜つみてん
Today fell spring rain, recalling catalpa bows that one bends to string. If it but falls tomorrow, we will be picking young greens.
今日がスーパーの特売日じゃねーか
Isn't today the supermarket’s special sale day?!
